meanings: open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning
not clear or decided

common: The lawyer's ambiguous statement left the jury confused.
The instructions were ambiguous, so I wasn't sure what to do.
fun: His answer was as ambiguous as a politician's promise.
The fortune cookie's message was delightfully ambiguous, promising both great wealth and sudden change.

translations.en: open to more than one interpretation; unclear or inexact

meanings: open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning
not clear or decided
意义不明确的
有多种解释的
to represent (something) as being larger, greater, better, or worse than it is

common: Fishermen often exaggerate the size of the fish they caught.
Don't exaggerate the difficulties; the task is manageable.
fun: He didn't just stretch the truth, he exaggerated it into a yoga pose.
My hunger wasn't just a rumble; I exaggerated it to a lion's roar.

translations.en: to represent something as being larger, better, or worse than it really is

meanings: to represent (something) as being larger, greater, better, or worse than it is
夸大
言过其实
a supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation
a proposition assumed as a premise in an argument

common: The scientist's hypothesis was that the plant would grow faster with more light.
We are testing the hypothesis that social media use affects sleep patterns.
fun: My hypothesis is that the missing cookies were taken by a crumb-loving ghost.
The detective's wild hypothesis turned out to be correct, much to everyone's astonishment.

translations.en: a proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence, a starting point for investigation

meanings: a supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation
a proposition assumed as a premise in an argument
假说
前提
certain to happen; unavoidable

common: After the scandal, his resignation seemed inevitable.
With their star player injured, defeat was inevitable.
fun: The inevitable result of teaching a parrot to swear is a very embarrassing dinner party.
As soon as I washed the car, the inevitable rain began to fall.

meanings: certain to happen; unavoidable
必然发生的
无法避免的
to place or deal with (close together or side by side), especially for comparison or contrast

common: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with his later paintings.
The film juxtaposes scenes of wealth with scenes of poverty.
fun: The chef loved to juxtapose unexpected flavors, like chocolate and chili.
Juxtaposing his tiny kitten with a giant St. Bernard made for a hilarious photo.

translations.en: to place or deal with close together for contrasting effect

meanings: to place or deal with (close together or side by side), especially for comparison or contrast
将...并置
把...放在一起对比
a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable, to suggest a resemblance.
a thing regarded as representative or symbolic of something else, especially something abstract.

common: The poet used the metaphor of a stormy sea to describe her inner turmoil.
'Time is a thief' is a common metaphor for how quickly life passes.
fun: His explanation was so confusing it felt less like a metaphor and more like a secret code.
My cat's relationship with the laser pointer is a perfect metaphor for the futility of desire.

meanings: a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable, to suggest a resemblance.
a thing regarded as representative or symbolic of something else, especially something abstract.
一种修辞手法，用一事物暗示另一事物
比喻的说法
a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
a situation, person, or thing that combines contradictory features or qualities.

common: The statement 'less is more' is a classic paradox.
It is a paradox that standing is more tiring than walking.
fun: The paradox of my diet is that I think about food more now than I ever did before.
He embodied the paradox of being a fiercely private celebrity.

meanings: a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
a situation, person, or thing that combines contradictory features or qualities.
看似矛盾但可能正确的说法
自相矛盾的情况或人
able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
(of a substance or object) able to recoil or spring back into shape after bending, stretching, or being compressed.

common: Children are often remarkably resilient in the face of adversity.
This type of plastic is highly resilient and won't crack easily.
fun: My phone is surprisingly resilient, surviving multiple drops onto concrete.
She had the resilient optimism of a weed growing through a crack in the pavement.

meanings: able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
(of a substance or object) able to recoil or spring back into shape after bending, stretching, or being compressed.
能迅速从困难中恢复的
有弹性的，适应力强的
to examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.

common: The committee will scrutinize the budget proposal for any irregularities.
He scrutinized the document, looking for any hidden clauses.
fun: My dog scrutinized the new piece of furniture as if it were an alien artifact.
I had to scrutinize the menu for ten minutes before I realized I was holding it upside down.

meanings: to examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.
仔细或批判性地检查
审视
lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
(of a person) staying or working in a place for only a short time.
a person who is staying or working in a place for only a short time.

common: The feeling of sadness was only transient and soon passed.
The city has a large population of transient workers during the summer.
fun: My interest in learning the accordion was charmingly transient.
The cat treated us not as owners, but as transient staff in her royal palace.

meanings: lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
(of a person) staying or working in a place for only a short time.
a person who is staying or working in a place for only a short time.
持续很短时间的
转瞬即逝的
短暂停留的人
A meaningless string of characters, often produced by random keystrokes, used as a placeholder or test data.
In computing, often refers to temporary or nonsensical data.

common: When testing the form, just enter 'sdf' in the username field.
The file was filled with 'sdf' as dummy content.
fun: His password was so secure it looked like pure 'sdf' to anyone glancing over his shoulder.
The cat walked across the keyboard and authored a novel titled 'sdf sdf sdf'.

translations.zh: 无意义字符串（常用占位符）

meanings: 指随意敲击键盘产生的无意义字符串，常用作占位文本或测试数据
在计算机领域，常指代临时、无具体含义的数据
A meaningless string of random letters, not a valid word in the English language.
Often used for testing or to represent gibberish.

common: The system flagged 'kljlklkjlkjlkjlkjkljlkjlkjkljlkkjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjj' as an invalid input.
He accidentally typed a long sequence of j's and k's, creating a nonsense word.
fun: The cat walked across the keyboard and produced a masterpiece titled 'kljlklkjlkjlkjlkjkljlkjlkjkljlkkjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjj'.
In their secret code, 'kljlklkjlkjlkjlkjkljlkjlkjkljlkkjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjj' meant 'the cookies are in the jar'.

meanings: 一个由随机字母组成的无意义字符串，不是英语中的有效单词。
通常用于测试或表示胡言乱语。
A meaningless combination of letters that does not represent any known English word.
Commonly used as a placeholder or example.

common: Please do not use placeholder text like 'kljlkjlkjklkmjmlkjlk' in the final document.
The toddler babbled a string of sounds that sounded like 'kljlkjlkjklkmjmlkjlk'.
fun: The alien's greeting, translated loosely, was 'kljlkjlkjklkmjmlkjlk', which filled the humans with both wonder and confusion.
His password was so secure it looked like 'kljlkjlkjklkmjmlkjlk', and he immediately forgot it.

meanings: 一个无意义的字母组合，不代表任何已知的英语单词。
常被用作占位符或示例。
used before a singular noun that is countable when it is mentioned for the first time and does not represent a particular person or thing
used before a singular noun that represents any member of a class or group
used to express a rate, ratio, or quantity

common: I saw a dog in the park.
She earns $50 an hour.
fun: A wizard is never late, nor is he early; he arrives precisely when he means to.
It was a dark and stormy night, and a lone figure walked down a deserted street.

meanings: （用于可数名词或单数名词前，表示未曾提到的）一（个）
（表示非特指的任何）一个
（用于表示数量）每一（个）
a round fruit with firm, white flesh and red, green, or yellow skin
the tree that produces this fruit

common: She packed an apple in her lunchbox.
The recipe calls for one large, red apple.
fun: My new phone is so shiny, I'm afraid to drop it—it's the apple of my eye.
He claimed his idea was completely original, but everyone knew it didn't fall far from the corporate apple tree.

meanings: 苹果（水果）
苹果树
类似苹果的果实
the round fruit of a tree of the rose family, which typically has thin red or green skin and crisp flesh
the tree which bears this fruit
one of two or more available possibilities
a choice limited to one of two or more possibilities
(of one or more things) available as another possibility or choice
relating to activities that depart from or challenge traditional norms

common: We need to consider an alternative plan in case it rains.
She chose the healthier alternative for lunch.
fun: His alternative to a boring Friday night was learning to juggle flaming torches.
The cat presented an alternative interpretation of the 'no pets on the furniture' rule.

meanings: 可供选择的事物，替代方案
非主流的选择（如另类摇滚）
可供替代的，供选择的
非传统的，另类的
having or showing a strong desire and determination to succeed
(of a plan or piece of work) intended to satisfy high aspirations and therefore difficult to achieve

common: She is an ambitious young lawyer aiming for a partnership.
The company announced an ambitious plan to expand into three new countries.
fun: His most ambitious project yet was teaching his goldfish to play fetch.
The squirrel set an ambitious goal of storing exactly one acorn in every backyard on the block.

meanings: 有雄心的，有抱负的
耗资巨大的，艰巨的
This is not a standard English word. It appears to be a misspelling, a nonce word, a product code, or a random string of characters.

common: The string 'applevcbhghufguvugvgv' was found in the data log.
I received an error message containing 'applevcbhghufguvugvgv'.
fun: My cat walked across the keyboard and typed 'applevcbhghufguvugvgv'.
The secret password in the sci-fi novel was 'applevcbhghufguvugvgv'.

translations.zh: 无标准翻译（疑似随机字符串）

meanings: 这不是一个标准的英语单词。它可能是一个拼写错误、一个虚构词、一个产品代码或一串随机字符。
a small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur, a short snout, and retractable claws
any member of the family Felidae, including lions, tigers, etc.
a malicious or spiteful woman (archaic/slang)

common: The black cat sat on the windowsill, watching the birds.
She decided to adopt a rescue cat from the shelter.
fun: My cat, Sir Whiskers, believes he is the true ruler of our household.
In a shocking turn of events, the cat learned to open the fridge, prioritizing tuna over world domination.

meanings: 猫，猫科动物
（尤指家养的）猫
猫皮
（对女人恶毒的）泼妇
a domesticated carnivorous mammal with four legs, a tail, and a keen sense of smell
a contemptible or worthless man
to follow (someone) closely and persistently
to cause persistent trouble or distress to

common: The dog barked loudly at the mail carrier.
She takes her dog for a walk every evening.
fun: My dog believes he's a tiny, furry philosopher pondering the meaning of the squeaky toy.
The detective doggedly pursued the suspect through the crowded market.

meanings: 狗，犬
卑鄙小人，无赖
跟踪，尾随
困扰，纠缠
a person whom one knows, likes, and trusts
a person who supports or favors something
an acquaintance

common: She is my closest friend and confidante.
He made many friends during his time at university.
fun: My phone is my best friend; it knows all my secrets and never leaves my side.
The old tree in the garden was a silent friend, witnessing generations of family stories.

meanings: 朋友，友人
支持者，赞助人
相识的人
